developmentContext.title: Development Context
developmentContext.content:
Vanuatu is an archipelago of 83 islands, of which 68 islands are permanently inhabited. Of all the islands, 14 have a surface area of more than 100 square kilometres. Its islands are young, small and highly disturbed as a result of frequent cyclones, seismic and volcanic activity. English, French and Bislama (local form of Pidgin English) are recognised as the official languages, with over 100 indigenous languages as well. Nearly 80 percent of the population live on the twelve largest islands

The country has a reasonable natural resource base for achieving sustainable human development. The economy is based primarily on subsistence or small-scale agriculture, which provides a living for 65 percent of the population (36% of which is aged between 1-14).

Fishing, offshore financial services, and tourism are mainstays of the economy. Having an Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of 735,893 square kilometers, it possesses substantial marine resources. The main exports are copra (dried coconut flesh), coconut oil, cocoa, coffee, kava root, beef and timber.

successesInDevelopment.title: Successes in Development
successesInDevelopment.content:
Vanuatu has made strides in social welfare services. In 2018, 100 % of the country's poor population were receiving social assistance cash benefits. In addition, The proportion of the population with access to electricity increased from 18.0 % in 1994 to 62.8% in 2017.

Similarly, between 1990 and 2019, Vanuatu’s life expectancy at birth increased by 5.7 years, mean years of schooling increased by 0.6 years and expected years of schooling increased by 1.6 years. It’s GNI per capita increased by about 8.8 percent between 1990 and 2019.  Despite the development challenges that Vanuatu faces, the Pacific island country has made much progress to be proud of. Next year, Vanuatu is set to become only the sixth country to graduate from Least Developed Country Status. The Solomon Islands are on track to graduate in 2024.

challengesInDevelopment.title: Challenges in Development
challengesInDevelopment.content:
Vanuatu’s 2019 HDI of 0.609 is below the average of 0.631 for countries in the medium human development group and below the average of 0.747 for countries in East Asia and the Pacific. The proportion of the population living below the extreme poverty line was 13.0 % in 2010.

There are some negative trends with respect to living standard measures. The proportion of the population using basic sanitation services declined from 61.8 % in 2000 to 34.1% in 2017. The share of renewable energy in the total final energy consumption declined from 48.7 % in 2000 to 36.1% in 2017.

Environmental degradation, pollution and waste continue to undermine livelihood opportunities and people’s health. Policy coordination, public engagement and legal enforcement to ensure environmental protection and natural resource management are often weak and under-value the contribution of natural resources and environmental health to prosperity.  Vanuatu and the entire Pacific subregion have the highest fossil fuel dependency of any region. While a number of countries have ambitious renewable energy production targets, they are not linked to deployment capacities and known local energy resources. The great majority of people in Vanuatu lack access to modern energy services such as for cooking or lighting.
